class="img_cptn">Smog envelopes Mumbai (File photo)</span></section><div class="article_content clearfix"><arttextxml><div class="section1"><div class="Normal">NEW DELHI: As the government works on a mechanism to assist big cities in battling air pollution, Mumbai is set to get the highest grant of Rs 488 crore from the Centre’s Rs 4,400 crore fund which is earmarked exclusively for cities with more than one million population in states to improve air quality during 2020-21.

<br>
<br>Delhi may miss this assistance despite figuring among the most polluted cities in the country as the fund would only be meant for ‘million plus’ population cities in states.

                    })()
                    
                      
                
            </script><br>
<br>The national capital, will, however continue to get support from the <a class="key_underline" href="https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/National-Clean-Air-Programme" pg="AS1_InlineMedia#AS1_https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/environment/pollution/mumbai-gets-lions-share-of-govts-pollution-fund/articleshow/74585292.cms~National Clean Air Programme-https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/National-Clean-Air-Programme">National Clean Air Programme</a> (pollution control scheme) of the environment ministry and other schemes of the agriculture ministry to deal with stubble-burning.
<br>
<br>Under the pollution control scheme, the environment ministry has, however, been allocated just Rs 460 crore for 122 ‘non-attainment’ cities across the country. Non-attainment cities are those which do not meet the national ambient air quality standards.
<br>
<br>At Rs 488 crore, share of Mumbai local body will be higher than the total money (Rs 460 crore) earmarked for the entire <a class="key_underline" href="https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/NCAP" pg="AS1_InlineMedia#AS1_https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/environment/pollution/mumbai-gets-lions-share-of-govts-pollution-fund/articleshow/74585292.cms~NCAP-https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/NCAP">NCAP</a> of the environment ministry. Besides NCAP, the Centre has in its budget for 2020-21 allocated Rs 4,400 crore to the urban development ministry for taking up clean air measures in ‘million plus’ cities.
<br>
<br>The break-up of financial assistance for these cities is recommended by the 15th Finance Commission. Forty-two of 50 such cities in states will get assistance from the fund. Remaining eight cities are kept out of its ambit as air quality is not a major issue there.
<br> 
<br> 
<div class="image" data-msid="74588891"><img src="https://static.toiimg.com/img/74588891/Master.jpg" alt="resize9 (1)"></div> 
<br>
<br>Noting the critical issue of air pollution in Delhi-NCR, the Commission recommended the Centre to constitute a committee, consisting of ministries of finance, environment and agriculture, state governments of Haryana, Punjab and Uttar Pradesh, to “devise, implement and monitor a time-bound action plan for pollution mitigation”.
<br>
<div class="last8brdiv"></div><br>After Mumbai, the second highest amount from the urban development ministry’s fund will be allocated to Kolkata (Rs 385 crore), followed by Bengaluru (Rs 279 crore), Hyderabad (Rs 234 crore) and Patna (Rs 204 crore).
<div class="last7brdiv"></div><br>
<div class="last6brdiv"></div><br>Half of the earmarked assistance will, however, be given to these cities based on their performance in year-on-year improvement in air quality. “The environment ministry will soon publish benchmarks for this purpose,” said an official, adding the performance related grant will be based on improvement in average annual concentrations of both PM 10 and PM2.5 (equal weightage of 50%) as calculated in January 2021.
<div class="last5brdiv"></div><br>
<div class="last4brdiv" data-topcmt-status="true"><div class="show_wdgt topcomment" data-plugin="show-comments"><div class="msg"><h2><span>Top</span> Comment</h2><span class="cmnttxt">They'll probably hire 1000 people with this fund, just to waste money. Should just invest it all into the locals and signal upgrading, so they run with more frequency, but no, Government doesn't work... <span class="detail_comment_link">Read More</span></span><span class="cmnttxt" data-type="full_top_cmnt" style="display:none;">They'll probably hire 1000 people with this fund, just to waste money. Should just invest it all into the locals and signal upgrading, so they run with more frequency, but no, Government doesn't work in the most efficient way, most of the money will go into creating unproductive jobs whose only job is to ask the centre for more allocation of funds into this pollution. </span><span class="cmntauthor">Ajinkya Taware</span></div><input type="button" data-plugin="show-comments" data-type="allcomment" class="btn" value="See All Comments" pg="TopComment#SeeAllComments#https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/environment/pollution/mumbai-gets-lions-share-of-govts-pollution-fund/articleshow/74585292.cms"><input type="button" data-plugin="show-comments" data-showtype="autofocus" data-type="addcomment" class="btn" value="Add Comment" pg="TopComment#AddComment#https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/environment/pollution/mumbai-gets-lions-share-of-govts-pollution-fund/articleshow/74585292.cms"></div></div><br>The environment ministry had launched NCAP in January last year and set a mid-term (five-year) target to reduce air pollution by 20-30% by 2024, taking 2017 as base year.
<div class="last3brdiv"></div><br>
<div class="last2brdiv"></div><br>The first instalment to the cities from Rs 4,400 crore fund will be used for taking multiple air quality improvement measures, including capacity- building of local bodies. 
<div class="last1brdiv"></div><br>

            <p class="short_comment">They'll probably hire 1000 people with this fund, just to waste money. Should just invest it all into the locals and signal upgrading, so they run with more frequency, but no, Government doesn't work in the most efficient way, most of the money will go into creating unproductive jobs whose only job is to ask the centre for more allocation of funds into this pollution. 
            </p>

src="/thumb/msid-74585300,imgsize-44851,width-400,resizemode-4/74585300.jpg" data-imgid="74585300" alt="Smog envelopes Mumbai (File photo)" title="Smog envelopes Mumbai (File photo)"><span class="img_cptn">Smog envelopes Mumbai (File photo)</span></section><div class="article_content clearfix"><arttextxml><div class="section1"><div class="Normal">NEW DELHI: As the government works on a mechanism to assist big cities in battling air pollution, Mumbai is set to get the highest grant of Rs 488 crore from the Centre’s Rs 4,400 crore fund which is earmarked exclusively for cities with more than one million population in states to improve air quality during 2020-21.

<br>
<br>Delhi may miss this assistance despite figuring among the most polluted cities in the country as the fund would only be meant for ‘million plus’ population cities in states.
<div style="width:99%;margin: 10px auto 10px;" id="fluid-container"><div id="div-gpt-ad-1485328452682222244" data-size="fluid" class="webonly alC" data-google-query-id="CPTo17n8tOgCFbFDfQoduIsLvg" style="display: none;"><div id="google_ads_iframe_/7176/TOI/TOI_ROS/TOI_ROS_AS/TOI_ROS_AS_Mrec_MID_300_0__container__" style="border: 0pt none; width: 100%; height: 0%;"></div></div></div><script>
                
                    (function(){
                      var adContainer = '<div id="div-gpt-ad-1485328452682222244" data-size="fluid" data-adsslot="TOI/TOI_ROS/TOI_ROS_AS/TOI_ROS_AS_Mrec_MID_300" class="webonly alC"></div>';
                      var randomNumber = Math.random();
                      var isIndia = (window.geoinfo && window.geoinfo.CountryCode === 'IN') && (window.location.href.indexOf('outsideindia') === -1 );
                      console.log(isIndia && randomNumber < 0.9 );
                      if(isIndia){
                        // code for showing ctn ad
                         $('#fluid-container').remove();
                         return;
                      }	
                      $('.top2brdiv').remove();
                      $('#fluid-container').append(adContainer);
                    })()
                    
                      
                
            </script><br>
<br>The national capital, will, however continue to get support from the <a class="key_underline" href="https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/National-Clean-Air-Programme" pg="AS1_InlineMedia#AS1_https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/environment/pollution/mumbai-gets-lions-share-of-govts-pollution-fund/articleshow/74585292.cms~National Clean Air Programme-https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/National-Clean-Air-Programme">National Clean Air Programme</a> (pollution control scheme) of the environment ministry and other schemes of the agriculture ministry to deal with stubble-burning.
<br>
<br>Under the pollution control scheme, the environment ministry has, however, been allocated just Rs 460 crore for 122 ‘non-attainment’ cities across the country. Non-attainment cities are those which do not meet the national ambient air quality standards.
<br>
<br>At Rs 488 crore, share of Mumbai local body will be higher than the total money (Rs 460 crore) earmarked for the entire <a class="key_underline" href="https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/NCAP" pg="AS1_InlineMedia#AS1_https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/environment/pollution/mumbai-gets-lions-share-of-govts-pollution-fund/articleshow/74585292.cms~NCAP-https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/NCAP">NCAP</a> of the environment ministry. Besides NCAP, the Centre has in its budget for 2020-21 allocated Rs 4,400 crore to the urban development ministry for taking up clean air measures in ‘million plus’ cities.
<br>
<br>The break-up of financial assistance for these cities is recommended by the 15th Finance Commission. Forty-two of 50 such cities in states will get assistance from the fund. Remaining eight cities are kept out of its ambit as air quality is not a major issue there.
<br> 
<br> 
<div class="image" data-msid="74588891"><img src="https://static.toiimg.com/img/74588891/Master.jpg" alt="resize9 (1)"></div> 
<br>
<br>Noting the critical issue of air pollution in Delhi-NCR, the Commission recommended the Centre to constitute a committee, consisting of ministries of finance, environment and agriculture, state governments of Haryana, Punjab and Uttar Pradesh, to “devise, implement and monitor a time-bound action plan for pollution mitigation”.
<br>
<div class="last8brdiv"></div><br>After Mumbai, the second highest amount from the urban development ministry’s fund will be allocated to Kolkata (Rs 385 crore), followed by Bengaluru (Rs 279 crore), Hyderabad (Rs 234 crore) and Patna (Rs 204 crore).
<div class="last7brdiv"></div><br>
<div class="last6brdiv"></div><br>Half of the earmarked assistance will, however, be given to these cities based on their performance in year-on-year improvement in air quality. “The environment ministry will soon publish benchmarks for this purpose,” said an official, adding the performance related grant will be based on improvement in average annual concentrations of both PM 10 and PM2.5 (equal weightage of 50%) as calculated in January 2021.
<div class="last5brdiv"></div><br>
<div class="last4brdiv" data-topcmt-status="true"><div class="show_wdgt topcomment" data-plugin="show-comments"><div class="msg"><h2><span>Top</span> Comment</h2><span class="cmnttxt">They'll probably hire 1000 people with this fund, just to waste money. Should just invest it all into the locals and signal upgrading, so they run with more frequency, but no, Government doesn't work... <span class="detail_comment_link">Read More</span></span><span class="cmnttxt" data-type="full_top_cmnt" style="display:none;">They'll probably hire 1000 people with this fund, just to waste money. Should just invest it all into the locals and signal upgrading, so they run with more frequency, but no, Government doesn't work in the most efficient way, most of the money will go into creating unproductive jobs whose only job is to ask the centre for more allocation of funds into this pollution. </span><span class="cmntauthor">Ajinkya Taware</span></div><input type="button" data-plugin="show-comments" data-type="allcomment" class="btn" value="See All Comments" pg="TopComment#SeeAllComments#https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/environment/pollution/mumbai-gets-lions-share-of-govts-pollution-fund/articleshow/74585292.cms"><input type="button" data-plugin="show-comments" data-showtype="autofocus" data-type="addcomment" class="btn" value="Add Comment" pg="TopComment#AddComment#https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/environment/pollution/mumbai-gets-lions-share-of-govts-pollution-fund/articleshow/74585292.cms"></div></div><br>The environment ministry had launched NCAP in January last year and set a mid-term (five-year) target to reduce air pollution by 20-30% by 2024, taking 2017 as base year.
<div class="last3brdiv"></div><br>
<div class="last2brdiv"></div><br>The first instalment to the cities from Rs 4,400 crore fund will be used for taking multiple air quality improvement measures, including capacity- building of local bodies. 
<div class="last1brdiv"></div><br>

            <p class="short_comment">They'll probably hire 1000 people with this fund, just to waste money. Should just invest it all into the locals and signal upgrading, so they run with more frequency, but no, Government doesn't work in the most efficient way, most of the money will go into creating unproductive jobs whose only job is to ask the centre for more allocation of funds into this pollution. 
            </p>

                        if(document.location.search.indexOf('geolocation=1') > -1) {
